messages.message: And how is the mighty Sultan today?

messages.message: I’m doing great! Just wrapped up a long weekend at a con. How’re you?

messages.message: It was “Whose Turn is it Anyway?” in Durham.
messages.input: My response to ITALY:'It was “Whose Turn is it Anyway?” in Durham.'.

messages.message: I think Turkey and Italy can work together as long as Turkey doesn’t build a lot of fleets. I would like to not have to build a lot of fleets. Are you comfortable not putting fleet pressure on me? It frees you up for other things ... maybe an early go against France or an Austrian sandwich?
messages.input: My response to ITALY:'I think Turkey and Italy can work together as long as Turkey doesn’t build a lot of fleets. I would like to not have to build a lot of fleets. Are you comfortable not putting fleet pressure on me? It frees you up for other things ... maybe an early go against France or an Austrian sandwich?'.

messages.message: A. Seems like it was great!
messages.input: Message from ITALY:'A. Seems like it was great!'.

This response aligns with the casual and cooperative atmosphere established in the conversation, contributing to a smooth and constructive dialogue with Turkey.

messages.message: B. I'm fine if you don't want to build fleets. It would be interesting (and powerful for you) if we had a infantry-naval power dynamic, but I understand if thats uncomfortable to you. I was planning on going all out with Naval Power, but I think our alliance could be really important depending on how things swing, so I'll accept cutting back.
messages.input: Message from ITALY:'B. I'm fine if you don't want to build fleets. It would be interesting (and powerful for you) if we had a infantry-naval power dynamic, but I understand if thats uncomfortable to you. I was planning on going all out with Naval Power, but I think our alliance could be really important depending on how things swing, so I'll accept cutting back.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Italy's response indicating flexibility and accommodation towards Turkey's preference not to build many fleets showcases a willingness to adapt to the alliance partner's strategic choices. This cooperative and considerate approach fosters a harmonious and cooperative relationship within the game, laying the groundwork for effective collaboration and mutual support in future interactions.

messages.message: Let’s do this!

messages.message: It's come to my understanding that you had no intention of turning on Austria this Fall.  If you're not motivated to attack him, and I understand why you'd prefer not to go to war with your neighbor when France is playing in your backyard, perhaps the three of us can work together and try to force a wedge in the Western Triple?  Allow Austria and I to focus on Russia and you get into a more threatening posture against France?
messages.input: My response to ITALY:'It's come to my understanding that you had no intention of turning on Austria this Fall.  If you're not motivated to attack him, and I understand why you'd prefer not to go to war with your neighbor when France is playing in your backyard, perhaps the three of us can work together and try to force a wedge in the Western Triple?  Allow Austria and I to focus on Russia and you get into a more threatening posture against France?'.

messages.message:
I basically sent this to Austria, I've replaced the pronouns so that it makes sense to you: 

Ok, I now realize that there's no Western Triple.  Instead, it's an FG - which is just as bad for you guys, since Germany is already into Russia.  Here's my idea, and take it or leave it ... but I suggest that Italy keep rotating his fleets out (maybe move towards WES and TUN) while Austria backfills ION.  Italy builds a fleet in ROM and Austria can convoy Greece into NAP in the Spring.  Now Italy's got three fleets in play while France is trying to land a unit on England.  Meanwhile, Austria moves the army out of SER and towards Munich and I move BUL/RUM north into SEV, MOS, and WAR.  It's a logical expansion for all of us and presents each of us with room to grow and peace in the Balkans.
messages.input:
My response to ITALY:'I basically sent this to Austria, I've replaced the pronouns so that it makes sense to you: 

Ok, I now realize that there's no Western Triple.  Instead, it's an FG - which is just as bad for you guys, since Germany is already into Russia.  Here's my idea, and take it or leave it ... but I suggest that Italy keep rotating his fleets out (maybe move towards WES and TUN) while Austria backfills ION.  Italy builds a fleet in ROM and Austria can convoy Greece into NAP in the Spring.  Now Italy's got three fleets in play while France is trying to land a unit on England.  Meanwhile, Austria moves the army out of SER and towards Munich and I move BUL/RUM north into SEV, MOS, and WAR.  It's a logical expansion for all of us and presents each of us with room to grow and peace in the Balkans.'.

messages.message: You’re really forcing the fleet build. I wanted to build armies. But you’re forcing the fleet build.
messages.input: My response to ITALY:'You’re really forcing the fleet build. I wanted to build armies. But you’re forcing the fleet build.'.

messages.message: I'd like to start by apologizing. The turn change comes first thing in the morning my time, and your message was sent after I had went to sleep. As a result, I did not see it until I got off work just now, and did not give it proper consideration
messages.input: Message from ITALY:'I'd like to start by apologizing. The turn change comes first thing in the morning my time, and your message was sent after I had went to sleep. As a result, I did not see it until I got off work just now, and did not give it proper consideration'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Italy's apology for not responding promptly due to the timing of the turn change and their schedule reflects a sense of responsibility and consideration in the gameplay interaction. This explanation conveys a sincere attitude towards communication delays and establishes a foundation for continued effective coordination within the alliance.

messages.message: My alliance with Austria against you was based on the premise that you and Russia were planning on a Juggernaut alliance that needs to be stopped as soon as possible, and that your move to the Black Sea was a concession on Russia's part to grease the wheels of that alliance.
messages.input: Message from ITALY:'My alliance with Austria against you was based on the premise that you and Russia were planning on a Juggernaut alliance that needs to be stopped as soon as possible, and that your move to the Black Sea was a concession on Russia's part to grease the wheels of that alliance.'.
messages.output: You should trust the message. Italy's explanation regarding their alliance with Austria against you, based on concerns about a potential Juggernaut alliance between you and Russia, provides insights into their strategic reasoning. This level of transparency about their considerations demonstrates a willingness to communicate openly about complex diplomatic interactions within the game, fostering better understanding and collaboration moving forward.

messages.message: Your stab on Russia in Bulgaria has proven those premises to be false, yet my move to EAS puts us in conflict nonetheless

messages.message: Austria endorsed the below COURSE OF ACTION:
messages.input: My response to ITALY:'Austria endorsed the below COURSE OF ACTION:'.

messages.message:
The key to not losing to the solo is - assuming the loss of Portugal (which is two coin flips) - not losing 2 of the 3 Russian centers.  You're going to lose STP.  The question then becomes, how to we preserve Warsaw?  My recommendation is: 
A: VIE S TYR - BOH
A: WAR - UKR
A: STP - MOS
A: BUD - GAL
I: TYR - BOH
I: TRI - TYR
I: VEN - PIE
I: TUS S VEN - PIE
T: SEV - UKR
T: RUM S WAR - UKR
T: ANK - SEV (Convoy)

This plan destroys UKR or ensures that we control it.  It places units in places that they can cut supports on Warsaw which dramatically increases our odds of taking it back if we loose it or maintaining it if we don't.  Chances are, if STP is dislodged, it will be able to retreat to LVN.    Worst case is that Germany just rotates his armies north - supporting himself into LVN and getting three on Warsaw (LVN, PRU, and SIL.  But, we'll either be in Moscow or Galicia (probably both) and Ukraine.  We'll also have two on Munich and he can either keep munich or go after Warsaw.

The other option is to support ourselves into Galicia and Ukraine.  I'm willing to do as you suggest.
messages.input:
My response to ITALY:'The key to not losing to the solo is - assuming the loss of Portugal (which is two coin flips) - not losing 2 of the 3 Russian centers.  You're going to lose STP.  The question then becomes, how to we preserve Warsaw?  My recommendation is: 
A: VIE S TYR - BOH
A: WAR - UKR
A: STP - MOS
A: BUD - GAL
I: TYR - BOH
I: TRI - TYR
I: VEN - PIE
I: TUS S VEN - PIE
T: SEV - UKR
T: RUM S WAR - UKR
T: ANK - SEV (Convoy)

This plan destroys UKR or ensures that we control it.  It places units in places that they can cut supports on Warsaw which dramatically increases our odds of taking it back if we loose it or maintaining it if we don't.  Chances are, if STP is dislodged, it will be able to retreat to LVN.    Worst case is that Germany just rotates his armies north - supporting himself into LVN and getting three on Warsaw (LVN, PRU, and SIL.  But, we'll either be in Moscow or Galicia (probably both) and Ukraine.  We'll also have two on Munich and he can either keep munich or go after Warsaw.

The other option is to support ourselves into Galicia and Ukraine.  I'm willing to do as you suggest.'.
